title: How to Prepare Rosemary for Hair

steps.headline: Rinse fresh rosemary with cool water.
steps.description: Shake to remove excess water, and then place the rosemary between paper towels to dry.

steps.headline: Hold 4 to 6 stems of rosemary upside-down by the stems.
steps.description: Gather the rosemary into a bunch.

steps.headline: Strip off the weaker, lower leaves with your fingernails.
steps.description: Leave the upper leaves, which are more pungent.

steps.headline: Place the rosemary in a paper sack with the stems extending through the open end of the bag.
steps.description: Gather the bag around the stems, then secure the bag and stems with a string or rubber band.

steps.headline: Hang the rosemary in a warm, dry room for at least 2 weeks, or until the leaves are dry and brittle.
Pull the leaves from the stems.
steps.description: Discard the stems and place the dry leaves in a resealable plastic bag or airtight container.

steps.headline: Use rosemary tea to make basic rosemary shampoo.
steps.description: Mix 1/4 cup of tea with 1 cup of liquid castile soap. Add a few drops of camphor oil immediately before you shampoo if you have dandruff. Squeeze in a small amount of lemon juice for oily hair. A few drops of lavender essential oil creates a soothing fragrance.

steps.headline: Add 1/2 cup of warm water to 1/2 cup of rosemary tea to make refreshing rosemary hair rinse.
steps.description: Pour the liquid slowly through your hair immediately after you shampoo, and then rinse your hair with warm water.

steps.headline: Add 2 to 3 drops of camphor oil to a cup of rosemary tea, then use the mixture as a tonic for dandruff or itchy scalp.
steps.description: Dip a cotton ball into the tonic, and then dab the tonic onto your scalp. Put on a plastic shower cap and leave the tonic on your scalp for 30 minutes, and then rinse.
